items.title: AI has broken the ARR startup metric
Apple remains committed to invest despite tariffs: ID gov’t
items.author: Todotua Pasaribu
items.summary:
- Indonesia’s Deputy Minister for Investment, Todotua Pasaribu, confirms Apple’s continued investments in Indonesia despite a potential 32% import tariff from the U.S.
- Apple’s ongoing projects remain unaffected, and the company has committed approximately 2.6 trillion rupiah (US$160 million) to local initiatives, including the Apple Academy and the Apple Professional Developer Academy.
- Indonesia uses market access as a leverage strategy to secure technology investments, reflecting a broader trend among emerging economies to attract capital and skills development.

items.title: A list of fundraising startups from Asia and beyond (Updated)
items.summary:
- A curated list of fundraising startups for subscribers is offered.
- Startups can sign up for listing to attract investors through email notifications.
- Investors can receive curated listings of fundraising startups through subscription.
- The article suggests reaching out if a startup succeeds in fundraising for potential coverage.

items.title: Online trading app Webull shares jump 375%, hits $30b market value
items.summary:
- Shares of Webull increased by nearly 375% on April 14, 2025, during its second day on the market after merging with SK Growth Opportunities Corp, a SPAC.
- This surge raised Webull's market capitalization to nearly US$30 billion.
- Founded in 2016, Webull offers trading for stocks, options, ETFs, and cryptocurrencies, boasting over 23 million users globally.
- Webull’s SPAC merger success contrasts with the broader SPAC market's downturn, which saw a significant drop in activations since 2021.
- Despite a modest revenue growth outlook of $390.2 million for 2024, Webull's valuation surge indicates strong investor interest in the retail trading platform sector.

items.title: AnyMind Group appoints five leaders to drive AI, digital shift
items.summary:
- AnyMind Group announces five leadership appointments on April 15, 2025, focusing on AI-driven business processes and digital transformation.
- Ryuji Takemoto promoted to Chief Product Officer; Shodai Fujita appointed Country Manager of Japan.
- Kiatisak Watcharapruk joins from Google as Managing Director of Creator Growth; Masaki Okawa from Procter & Gamble is now Managing Director of Strategy.
- Steven Tan takes on the role of Managing Director of Fulfillment, overseeing warehousing and distribution.
- AnyMind's strategy aims to capitalize on a growing BPaaS market projected to expand from $63.3 billion in 2023 to $92.9 billion by 2028, enhancing service delivery and operational efficiency.

items.title: Taiwanese chip-tech firm eyes US sales office
AMPED Malaysia
items.summary:
- The article discusses the AMPED Malaysia event which focuses on technology and entrepreneurship in Malaysia.
- It highlights key speakers, workshops, and networking opportunities available during the event.
- The event aims to foster collaboration and innovation within the Malaysian tech community.

items.title: Apple’s market cap hits $3t as tariff exemptions save billions
items.summary:
- Apple's market capitalization surpassed $3 trillion on April 14, 2025, following a 2% share increase.
- The surge was attributed to tariff exemptions on phones, computers, and chips, allowing Apple to save billions in potential costs.
- President Trump encouraged Apple to move manufacturing to the US while warning that tariff exemptions may only be temporary.

items.title: S Korea raises chip aid to $23.3b as US plans new tariff rates
items.summary:
- South Korea announces a support package of 33 trillion won (US$23.25 billion) for its semiconductor industry, a 25% increase from last year.
- Funding allocation for financial assistance in the sector rises to 20 trillion won (US$14.08 billion).
- The announcement coincides with impending new tariff rates on imported semiconductors from the US, as per President Trump's plans.

items.title: Singapore eases monetary policy as US tariffs hit growth
items.summary:
- The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a further easing of monetary policy amid expectations of zero economic growth in 2025.
- The GDP growth for the first quarter was 3.8%, below forecasts of 4.3%, prompting the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) to reduce its 2025 GDP forecast to 0%-2%.
- The MAS plans to decrease the rate of appreciation of the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER), marking the second policy adjustment of the year due to concerns over external pressures, including US tariffs and US-China trade tensions.

items.title: Meta to use EU user data for AI training
items.summary:
- Meta plans to use EU user data from Facebook and Instagram for training AI models, excluding private messages.
- Notifications will be sent to EU users via in-app messages and emails, including opt-out options.
- Previous plans to collect similar data were paused due to regulatory pressure in Ireland; today's move aims to enhance AI's cultural relevance.

items.title: Meituan, JD.com help export firms shift to domestic market
items.summary:
- Meituan and JD.com are collaborating to assist export firms in pivoting towards the domestic market.
- The strategy includes leveraging existing logistics and online platforms to enhance domestic sales.
- This shift comes in response to changing market conditions and a need for companies to adapt post-pandemic.

items.title: IPhone shipments up 10% as tariff fears rise
items.summary:
- iPhone shipments increased by 10% amid rising tariff concerns.
- The growth is attributed to market shifts and consumer adaptation.
- Apple is navigating challenges posed by international trade policies.

items.title: On-demand pay startup Tapcheck nets $225m in new funding
items.summary:
- Tapcheck raised US$225 million in financing, including a US$25 million series A extension from PeakSpan Capital and a US$200 million credit facility from Victory Park Capital.
- Founded in 2019, Tapcheck provides early access to earned wages and integrates with over 300 payroll systems.
- The on-demand pay market is growing due to financial stress among workers, projected to reach $26.74 billion by 2030.
- 84% of employers see financial wellness tools as key in reducing attrition, with Tapcheck claiming over 50% improvement in employee retention.
- The evolution to earned wage access (EWA) reflects a significant shift in financial services, moving away from traditional paycheck advances that created debt.

items.title: Apple supplier Qorvo appoints new directors after investor push
items.summary:
- Qorvo appointed Richard Clemmer and Christopher Koopmans as independent directors on April 15, 2025.
- The move follows activist investor Starboard Value's push to improve share performance, with a disclosed 7.7% stake in January 2025.
- Qorvo's board now consists of nine members, eight of whom are independent, enhancing industry knowledge and expertise.
- Clemmer and Koopmans bring significant experience from NXP Semiconductors and Marvell Technology, respectively.
- The smartphone chip market faces challenges, as consumers extend device refresh cycles, impacting component suppliers like Qorvo significantly.

items.title: OpenAI introduces GPT-4.1 models with 1m tokens for automation
One Esports sheds staff in profit scramble
items.summary:
- One Esports laid off several staff members in February, including full-time employees and freelancers, affecting nearly the entire company.
- Over half of the gaming unit’s workforce was reportedly cut during this period based on LinkedIn data.
- Officially, only six full-time employees and some freelance staff members were confirmed to be laid off as part of Group One Holdings' strategy for shareholder value optimization.

items.title: Indonesian research startup Populix raises $4.3m series B
Nvidia to invest $500b in US AI infrastructure by 2029
items.summary:
- Nvidia plans to invest up to $500 billion in AI infrastructure in the US over the next four years.
- Partnerships with TSMC, Foxconn, and Wistron will be part of the initiative, with TSMC starting production of Nvidia's AI chips in Arizona.
- Foxconn and Wistron are expected to commence supercomputer manufacturing plants in Texas within 12 to 15 months.
- CEO Jensen Huang highlights that this move will help meet rising AI demand and strengthen supply chains.
- The investment matches Apple's commitment and reflects a significant shift in manufacturing back to the US, addressing supply chain vulnerabilities and creating jobs.

items.title: Zuckerberg denies suppressing competition in trial testimony
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg testified in an antitrust trial initiated by the FTC.
- The FTC claims that Meta’s acquisitions of Instagram (2012) and WhatsApp (2014) aimed to eliminate competition.
- A ruling to force Meta to divest these platforms could impact its revenue significantly; Instagram is projected to account for over half of Meta’s US advertising revenue by 2025.
- Zuckerberg denied suppressing competition and noted a shift in Meta’s focus to content sharing.
- The trial could continue into July, with the FTC needing to show that divesting assets would restore competition.

items.title: US-China financial decoupling could lead to $2.5t losses
items.summary:
- Goldman Sachs warns potential US-China financial decoupling could lead to losses of up to $2.5 trillion.
- US investors may need to sell $800 billion in Chinese stocks, while China could liquidate $1.3 trillion in US Treasuries and $370 billion in equities.
- Risk heightened after US Treasury Secretary suggested delisting Chinese firms from US exchanges.
- 286 Chinese companies are currently listed on US exchanges with significant valuations.
- Firms like Alibaba are pursuing dual listings in Hong Kong to mitigate risks associated with potential delisting.

items.title: Foxconn resumes iPhone hiring in China after tariff exemptions
items.summary:
- Foxconn Technology Group restarts hiring at its iPhone facility in Zhengzhou, China, after a brief pause.
- The company seeks temporary workers on three-month contracts, offering 20 yuan (US$2.70) per hour.
- Hiring resumed after the US exempted smartphones from new tariffs, but semiconductor products may still face future tariffs.

items.title: Xi Jinping urges Vietnam to counter trade bullying
items.summary:
- Chinese President Xi Jinping visited Vietnam, promoting collaboration against "unilateral bullying" and emphasizing free trade and supply chains.
- 45 agreements were signed, covering AI, agriculture, customs, and media to enhance economic collaboration.
- Vietnam, reliant on Chinese materials, aims to balance trade relations amid ongoing tensions.

items.title: Taiwan stocks may rebound on US tariff exemptions
items.summary:
- Taiwanese stocks are expected to recover due to US tariff exemptions on smartphones, PCs, servers, and chipmaking equipment.
- Analysts note ongoing market uncertainties due to potential future tariff changes and trade negotiations.
- The TAIEX index closed at 19,528.77 points on April 11, after a 8.31% weekly loss during a volatile trading period.
- Tariff exemptions are significant for Taiwan's role in global tech supply chains and electronics manufacturing.
- Taiwan has historically benefitted from US-China trade tensions, with a 21% increase in exports to the US in 2019.
- Analysts warn the current exemptions may be temporary, possibly replaced by new semiconductor tariffs soon.

items.title: A cheat sheet of M&As in India
items.summary:
- Since 2006, Tech in Asia has tracked India’s M&A landscape, noting a rise in landmark purchases and deal counts.
- The data presented includes only publicly disclosed M&A deals and excludes those with unknown deal sizes.
- Top five industries and ten acquirers in India’s M&A activity are highlighted, alongside a sortable database of deals.

items.title: Indonesia to import $19b of US goods to avoid Trump’s tariffs
Grab’s Anthony Tan champions “AI First, With Heart”
AI stock-analytics platform BridgeWise opens Dubai HQ
Swiggy expands 15-min food delivery to more Indian cities
items.summary:
- Swiggy expands its 15-minute food delivery service, SNACC, to Noida and Gurugram, after launching in Bengaluru earlier this year.
- The SNACC app offers a variety of food and beverages, including snacks and beverages, aimed at meeting the demand for quick deliveries in urban settings.
- This expansion targets corporate hubs with a large urban youth population, reflecting a strategic shift towards multi-app ecosystems in India's food tech market.

items.title: How J&T Express is delivering success
items.summary:
- In October 2023, J&T Express went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, raising over US$451 million.
- The company delivered nearly 25 billion parcels in 2024, equating to about three parcels for every person on Earth.
- Success attributed to focus on Southeast Asia and China, leveraging ecommerce partnerships like Shopee.
- Increasing competition as ecommerce players expand their logistics services.
- J&T is transitioning to a more asset-heavy model, investing in trucks and sorting centers for efficiency.

items.title: TSMC to focus on expansion, tariff impact at investor meeting
items.summary:
- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) will hold its investor conference on **April 17, 2025**.
- TSMC plans a **$100 billion** investment in Arizona, which includes two wafer fabs and a research and development center to counteract potential US tariffs on semiconductors.
- Recent US trade policy changes have led to economic uncertainties that affect the semiconductor industry.

items.title: SG-based women’s health brand bags $2.7m pre-series A
items.author: Maya Kale, Mili Kale
items.summary:
- Moom Health, a Singapore-based women’s health supplement brand, raised S$3.5 million (US$2.66 million) in a pre-series A funding round.
- Investment led by Wipro Consumer Care Ventures with contributions from DSG Consumer Partners, Racer Ventures, and HPRY Holdings.
- Founded in 2021, Moom Health specializes in supplements tailored for Asian women's health needs.
- Funding will be used to expand product range, strengthen supply chain, and enter new markets, specifically Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong.
- The women's health supplement market is attracting significant investor interest amid historical gaps in women's health research.
- Moom aims to address a market gap where 85% of Southeast Asian women struggle to find reliable female health information.
- Cultural sensitivities and barriers in Asian communities necessitate targeted health solutions for women.

items.title: Naver targets tourists with ‘Be Local’ Seoul campaign
items.summary:
- South Korea’s Naver launched the ‘Be Local’ campaign aimed at foreign tourists, which runs until May 13, 2025.
- The campaign highlights popular local spots in Seoul, including Myeong-dong, Itaewon, Hannam-dong, and Seongsu-dong.
- It offers deals at local favorites and collaborates with brands like Olive Young, Innisfree, and Musinsa for coupons and limited-edition merchandise.
- Naver Map features, supporting multiple languages, include translated reviews and custom filters for tourists.
- The campaign arises amid Google seeking access to South Korea's high-precision map data, potentially affecting Naver's dominance.

items.title: Delhi unveils EV policy phase 2, set to create 20k jobs
items.summary:
- The Delhi government is implementing the second phase of its Electric Vehicle (EV) Policy.
- This initiative is expected to create about 20,000 jobs in areas such as charging station operations and battery recycling.
- The policy is pending approval from the central government.
- Proposed measures include banning new petrol two-wheeler registrations by August 15, 2026, and fossil fuel three-wheelers by August 15, 2025.
- Plans include establishing 13,200 public charging stations and electrifying public transport fleets.

items.title: South Korea chemical firm Oci halts Malaysia IPO plan: sources
items.summary:
- Oci Holdings Co. has paused plans for its Malaysian polysilicon business IPO due to global stock market fluctuations.
- The preparations for the IPO are slowed, but not officially canceled, and other options are being evaluated.
- The polysilicon industry faces challenges from an oversupply situation, with a significant drop in prices and production capacity utilizations.

items.title: IMF: Saudi Arabia leads GCC in data center development
items.summary:
- The IMF recognized Saudi Arabia as a leader in data center development within the GCC.
- Saudi Arabia's digital infrastructure progress includes key achievements from the Saudi Data and Artificial Intelligence Authority (SDAIA) established in 2019.
- The Personal Data Protection Law, enacted in September 2023, enhances data governance and aligns with global standards while focusing on local control.
- Saudi data centers are praised for their energy efficiency and adherence to international standards.
- The report ties Saudi Arabia’s digital transformation to a larger economic diversification strategy linked to Vision 2030, emphasizing significant ICT sector contributions to GDP by 2023.

items.title: KKR taps former CIA director to lead Middle East push
items.summary:
- KKR appoints former CIA director to drive its initiatives in the Middle East.
- The move is part of KKR's strategy to expand its global investment footprint.
- The new leadership aims to leverage relationships and insights from KKR's previous engagements in the region.

items.title: Indian fintech unicorn Cred to raise $200m funding
items.summary:
[Cred is planning to raise $200 million in funding.]
[The company has been valued at over $1.5 billion.]
[This funding round aims to support its expansion and growth strategies.]

items.title: S Korea’s Fadu, Adata team up to develop custom solid-state drives
items.summary:
- South Korean companies Fadu and Adata announced a collaboration to develop custom solid-state drives (SSDs).
- This partnership aims to enhance SSD performance tailored for specific customer needs.
- The new SSDs are expected to cater to markets in gaming, content creation, and enterprise solutions.

items.title: Indian surveillance firm Optimized Electrotech nets $6m series A
items.summary:
- Optimized Electrotech raised US$6 million in a series A funding round.
- Investment was co-led by Blume Ventures and Mela Ventures with additional participation from others.
- Funds will be used to develop AI-based surveillance systems and expand globally.
- The company plans to launch a space-tech subsidiary and seek another US$5 million from semiconductor companies in six months.
- Since its founding in 2017, it has raised approximately $7.38 million across six funding rounds.
- Surveillance tech market is projected to grow significantly, driven by AI and advanced analytics.
- The company's future focus includes space surveillance and addressing challenges in the sector.

items.title: Trump’s tariffs: Thailand to negotiate with US on April 21
items.summary:
- Thailand is set to negotiate with the US regarding tariffs introduced by Trump on April 21.
- The negotiations aim to address the impacts of these tariffs on Thai exports.
- These discussions are part of ongoing efforts to manage trade relations between Thailand and the US.

items.title: Addressing First Frontier Borneo Capital’s response to our article
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Tech in Asia responded to criticism from Melissa Ong, CEO of Impact Circle regarding their reporting on FFBC's term sheet.
- Ong accused Tech in Asia of malice in publishing the article before a FFBC awards event, which Tech in Asia denied, stating unawareness of the event.
- Tech in Asia claims Ong had the opportunity to comment before the article was published but chose not to due to an ongoing due diligence process.
- The original article was updated to clarify that quoted founders were not offered the specific term sheet in question, an issue which Ong raised.
- Kevin Brockland's expertise was defended as independent despite his advisory role with Ong's organization.
- Tech in Asia has made the original article freely accessible after Ong's unauthorized sharing of it online.

items.title: Dorsey, Musk call for end to intellectual property laws
items.summary:
- Jack Dorsey calls for the deletion of all intellectual property (IP) laws, supported by Elon Musk.
- Their comments arise amid legal challenges against AI companies, particularly regarding copyright issues in training data.
- Supporters argue for automated penalties instead of a traditional IP system, while critics fear it would disadvantage creators.
- Recent lawsuits consolidate claims from authors alleging unauthorized use of their works by AI firms like OpenAI.
- This moment reflects ongoing tensions between content creators and evolving technologies in the IP landscape.

items.title: Apple leads tech stock gains after US tariff exemptions
items.summary:
- Apple shares jumped over 6% in Frankfurt following US tariff exemptions on electronics mainly from China.
- Other tech companies also gained, with Nvidia up over 3%, Dell Technologies climbing 6.3%, and ASML gaining 2.8%.
- Nasdaq futures increased by 1.6% during early European trading.
- US President Donald Trump announced that new tariffs on imported semiconductors will be revealed soon.
- The exemptions cover around $385 billion in imports for 2024, significantly reducing tax rates on exempted electronics from 145% to 5%. 
- Tariff exemptions are a significant change from previous protective tariff policies starting in 2018.
- Despite exemptions for consumer electronics, semiconductors were highlighted as a focus for future tariffs.
- Companies that diversified supply chains away from China will navigate the tariff landscape more effectively, as shown by the market response.

items.title: AI cybersecurity firm Armis plans IPO, targets $1b ARR
items.summary:
- AI cybersecurity firm Armis is planning an IPO.
- The company is targeting to achieve $1 billion in annual recurring revenue (ARR).
- The strategic move is part of Armis's growth and expansion plans in the cybersecurity sector.

items.title: Australian fintech firm completes $19m Bankit acquisition in India
SG-based agri group Olam to cut debt with $2b stake sale
PS5 price increase of 25% in Europe
items.summary:
- Sony raises PS5 prices in Europe and the UK by approximately 25%, effective April 14, 2025.
- New prices: €500 (US$540) in Europe and £430 (US$564.16) in the UK.
- Price hike cited due to inflation and affects Australia and New Zealand as well.
- This increase deviates from traditional console pricing strategies, which typically involve price cuts mid-lifecycle.
- Broader economic pressures, including import tariffs and inflation rates rising, influence the decision.
- Gaming hardware faces margin pressures amid a maturing market and rising development costs.

items.title: India’s BluSmart partners with Uber after ending services
AI Agents: licensed to get things done
items.author: Scott
items.summary:
- Agentic AI is gaining traction as a new technology that automates tasks like arranging travel and paying bills.
- Despite its potential, development in Southeast Asia is lagging due to caution from startups and investors about adopting new tech quickly.
- The agentic AI market is projected to reach a value of USD 197 billion by 2034, yet many companies are hesitant to become early adopters, opting to wait and see how the landscape evolves instead.
